Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>Colin,
>
>The prey capture is a nice demo- showing the sensor range definitely
>helps too.  
>
Thanks. I made a further change so that the sensor sectors are now shown 
also.

>You mentioned your imperfect results and I was thinking
>this may be due to your style of evaluation as opposed to your NEAT
>implementation.  For example, do you start each trial from a random
>position (either the prey or the predator)?  Or is something
>randomized about the prey? 
>
Yes. The agent starts a random position at least 4 units from a wall. 
The prey is then placed at a random angle between 2 and 4 units away. 
The prey's movement is also partially random, basically it's probability 
of moving away from the agent increases as the agent gets closer - so at 
a large distance the prey moves completely randomly.

> Randomization can cause noise in the
>evaluation, which means something looks like a champ might just be a
>lucky break, which can wreak havoc with fitness consistency.  It
>sometimes makes more sense to make things deterministic, even if that
>is counterintuitive.
>  
>
Ok I've just made a few changes to always start in the centre, and to 
perform 16 tests which are basically placing the prey at a distance of 4 
at 16 different angles (0, 22.5, 45, etc). This still leaves the random 
prey movement which I'll set to always move directly away from the agent 
for the initial moves, leaving movement to be partialy random from 
thereon. This isn't so bad since the main problem is to get the agent to 
remember where the prey was last seen before it moved out of sensor 
range during the initial steps - the subsequent increases in difficulty 
by increasing the speed of the prey aren't actually necessary IMHO.

Another point is that I do try to counteract the effects of noise by 
periodically re-evaluating members of the population that persist from 
generation to generation, therefore one lucky result will only skew the 
search for a while. Of course you may get one(or more) lucky result per 
generation, so this isn't a perfect solution by any means. In fact I may 
scrap this approach altogether, it was just a temprary hack really.
 
Anyway I'll let you know how it goes, my gut feeling here is that you're 
right but that there is also a problem elsewhere. Therefore my overall 
strategy for the moment is to port the pole balancing problem domain 
from the original NEAT and see how SharpNEAT performs in comparison.

Thanks for the feedback,

Colin.
